fullDescription.intro:
This node analyses documents and extracts relevant keywords using cooccurrence statistics as described in "Keyword extraction from a single document using word co-occurrence statistical information" by Y.Matsuo and M. Ishizuka.
First, the most frequent terms (see node settings) are extracted and then clustered together using the Jensen-Shannon divergence and Mutual Information measures. Once this is done, each term is ranked in decreasing order of the deviation between their expected cluster cooccurrence and the actual observed cooccurrence value. The terms with the highest divergence are returned as keywords.
A term can be considered as member of a cluster if it is similar to all the terms inside it according to at least one of the similarity measures. If more than one cluster meets this condition, the one with the highest average score will be used. If no cluster is similar, a new one is created.
Setting the console's output level to DEBUG will make this node display the contents of the clusters and also the similarity between terms.
fullDescription.option: The number of keywords to extract per document.

option.name: Percentage of unique terms in the document to use for the chi-square measures

fullDescription.option: The percentage of the set of unique terms in the document to use for the term clusters. The article this node is based on provides 30% as a rule of thumb.

If this option is checked, the node will only compare terms based on their word content. In other words, tags and any other meta information will be ignored. This will not affect the output documents, only the way they are analysed.

Terms whose pointwise mutual information score is greater than or equal to this value will be considered as similar and thus clustered together.
This similarity measure typically ranges from 0 to infinity but has been normalized from 0 to 1 using arctan(value)/(pi/2).

Terms whose normalized L1 norm score is greater than or equal to this value will be considered as similar and thus clustered together.
This similarity measure ranges from 0 to 1 inclusively.

ports.dataIn: The input table which contains the documents to analyse.
ports.dataOut: The output table which contains (keyword term, deviation value, associated document) tuples.
